intro: Oreinotinus wendlandii, commonly known as the Wendland’s mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of host trees. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and small, fleshy berries. The plant lacks true roots and absorbs water and nutrients through its stems, which are specialized for attachment to the host. It is native to parts of Central and South America, where it thrives in humid, tropical environments. Due to its parasitic nature, it can have significant ecological impacts on its host species.
